text:
Hello again content friends,
About a month ago I talked about “JOY” as a marketing KPI for an upcoming project of ours at Postmark. Follow-up: the project is live today, and if you have any time to check it… I’d love to know if it _actually_ brought you any joy :slightly_smiling_face:

For context: this is *the first ever* webcomic to show you exactly what happens to your emails after you hit the ‘send’ button. It features the Wild West, dog puns, a gang of nosey phishers, & spam watchdogs :dog: :face_with_cowboy_hat: :nose:

→ <https://www.producthunt.com/posts/postmark-express-the-comic>

attachments.fallback:
[September 15th, 2021 4:04 PM] fio: Hey content strategists,
Have you ever used non-traditional KPIs to measure success—for example: amount of JOY delivered to an audience? :thinking_face:

(context in the thread :arrow_down: )

text: Hey folks, noob question but *how and where do you find good freelance writers?* I'm ramping up content production for our blog that's focused on revenue teams and startups. Alternatively, if you are or know a good freelance writer, please DM me their details. TIA!

elements.text: Hey folks, noob question but
how and where do you find good freelance writers?
I'm ramping up content production for our blog that's focused on revenue teams and startups. Alternatively, if you are or know a good freelance writer, please DM me their details. TIA!

text:
Hi everyone! Would love some feedback. I'm a freelance B2B tech content strategist and I'm working on a one-day thought leadership workshop to help executives uncover stories that will help them (and their companies) stand out and reach the right people in a more genuine way. Basically, we know thought leadership is super important, but so many thought leaders/potential thought leaders are full of stories and short on time. After the workshop day, I'll put together a whole package of deliverables to help them + their marketing teams get started on the execution part.

My biggest questions are: 
1. Based on your own experience, do you think this is a valuable offering?
2. What would make you excited to have one of your own company execs do one of these workshop days?
3. Is there anything I just shared that made you say "I don't get it"?
Thank you!

text: Check Content Disrtibution's airtable link to Facebook groups for freelance writers and expats - great way to sift through a lot. Also let's not forget the simple things like actual job ads - making them official, coming from the website/business itself, gives the position authority and importance  :)

text: Alternatively, I've had some success with services like word agents (the content that I got wasn't that on-brand as I wanted it to be, but it did its job seo wise - ranked and brought interested readers to our services). Depending on what you want to do, such content writing services can help you a lot.

text: I like the concept; my biggest concern is the ROI given executives' lack of time. How will you show that is worth it for them to attend a one-day workshop versus just getting the deliverables? What is the value in the executive attending versus someone from content marketing/external communications (who most likely would be doing the actual writing)?

text: Hi Danielle! These are such good points to address. I have some ideas for proving ROI, but want to dig into this further.  I've worked with execs on this type of thing while I was in-house and at an agency and always saw a clear difference in the stories we uncovered when we were given concentrated blocks of time with an exec vs occasional short conversations that always stayed on the surface. That said, I think a few hours of 1:1 time throughout the day and time in between for me to get to work might be a more realistic format, with a month's worth of content delivered afterwards to take some pressure off the marketing team.

elements.text: Hi Danielle! These are such good points to address. I have some ideas for proving ROI, but want to dig into this further. text:
<@UUKNSAKUH>’s answer is :gem:

I personally like doing direct outreach to freelance writers and ask them to write for me/my client. My process is usually something like:

• Google around to find writers on, e.g., medium in my niche on the desired topic(s)
• Identify a few folks, find their email addresses using <http://Hunter.io|Hunter.io> or similar
• Outreach over email (“Hey, you available to write freelance on $topic for money?“)
• Have a conversation over email/phone
• Hand them a test paid writing project
Downside: it’s more work.

Upside: Really high success rates + really good writers.

text:
Lots of good talent floating around LinkedIn as well. As a B2B content strategist & writer, that’s where all my current clients have found me. 

All you have to do is search keywords on the platform. (Those who are active & have optimized profiles will show up higher in the results.) 

When you find someone who looks promising, aside from checking out their experience, recos, etc, also check out their “Recent Activity” section for even MORE options. A lot of writers are connected to other writers in their industry and engage with their posts.

text: So, I work for Miro...but yes, I use Miro (online whiteboard). :slightly_smiling_face: It's fantastic if you're a visual thinker and you can use slides (we call them frames), shapes, etc. There are integrations with lots of tools, so very easy to link out.
